items.title: Angkor’s Urban Environs, Mapped From Above
items.abstract: Using airborne laser-scanning technology, archaeologists have been able to map the highly engineered landscape now hidden under jungle and rice fields that surrounded the ancient temple complex.
keywords: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

items.title: Dvorak Is One Casualty of the City’s Heat Wave
items.abstract: New York City’s heat was so intense on Tuesday night that the Philharmonic shortened its final free outdoor concert in the Bronx.

items.title: When the New York City Subway Ran Without Rails
items.abstract: In 1870, Alfred Ely Beach, an inventor and publisher, introduced the city’s first subway, which ran in a pneumatic tunnel.

items.title: Privacy Fears Grow as Cities Increase Surveillance
items.abstract: A program in Oakland, Calif., is one of the latest and most contentious examples of cities using big data technology, and federal dollars, for routine law enforcement.

items.title: Daily Report: Fears for Privacy as Cities Widen Surveillance Efforts
items.abstract: A program in Oakland is one of the latest and most contentious examples of cities using big data technology, and federal dollars, for routine law enforcement.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Drone Scare Near New York City Shows Hazard Posed to Air Travel
items.abstract: The shutdown of Newark Liberty International Airport on Tuesday reminded travelers how vulnerable airports are to the threat of wayward drones.
keywords: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey

items.title: Selling Condoms or Pet Food? An Unexpected Bible of Million-Dollar Opportunities
items.abstract: Since 1873, the City of New York has put out a daily paper that is essential reading for those who want to do business with the city.

items.title: Why Midsize Cities Struggle to Catch Up to Superstar Cities
items.abstract: For decades, smaller metropolitan areas closed the income gap with bigger, richer ones, but no longer. So places like Winston-Salem, N.C., are trying to lay a new foundation for prosperity.

items.title: A Father-Son Split on Hong Kong Protests Shows City’s Generational Divide
items.abstract: As China celebrates the 70th anniversary of Communist rule, a father who fled the country wonders if he made the right decision, and why his son is protesting.

items.title: Tianjin, a city of 14 million near Beijing, starts testing all residents after Omicron surfaces.
items.abstract: The city also announced a raft of restrictions in an effort to contain the outbreak and trace its source.

items.title: In New York City Sewage, a Mysterious Coronavirus Signal
items.abstract: For the past year, scientists have been looking for the source of strange coronavirus sequences that have appeared in the city’s wastewater.

items.title: Russian Soldiers Took Their City, Then Their Homes
items.abstract: As Russian forces pushed toward Kyiv, they stormed an apartment complex in a nearby suburb and held residents hostage. Some of it was caught on camera.

items.title: Colin Cantwell, ‘Star Wars’ Spacecraft Designer, Dies at 90
items.abstract: He created the look of the X-wing and the Death Star; he also worked on “2001: A Space Odyssey,” “Close Encounters of the Third Kind” and “WarGames.”
keywords: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (Movie)

items.title: Polio Has Been Detected in New York City Wastewater, Officials Say
items.abstract: The detection of the virus in sewage suggests it is circulating in the city, Health Department officials said.
